awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a metallic nanoparticle synthesizer designed for academic, small-scale, and government laboratories. Currently, academic and small-scale laboratories either purchase or manually synthesize nanoparticles for utilization.  However, users report high expense and variations in quality from purchased nanoparticles, and manually synthesizing nanoparticles was found to be laborious and necessitated extensive training to yield viable nanoparticles with consistent performance.  The proposed technology automates the process and eliminates the need for manual intervention. In addition, the process may enable researchers to generate more accurate and consistent results by providing batch-to-batch reproducibility and control over the physical dimensions of the nanoparticles produced.  This may have an impact on the development of advanced biosensors, nanomedicine, and targeted drug delivery systems and improve healthcare outcomes.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an automated metallic nanoparticle synthesizer.  The proposed technology is designed to enhance efficiency of nanoparticle production, supplying laboratories with particles on demand and reducing the time and expense associated with outsourcing nanoparticle synthesis.  In addition, the proposed process may enhance control over the synthesis process, including the dimensions, morphology, and composition of the nanoparticles, enabling customization for specific research requirements.  The proposed synthesizer has been shown to generate 100 mL of 20 nm diameter gold nanoparticles. Additionally, it is equipped with an automated heat bed featuring feedback control and precise peristaltic pumps for accurate regulation of synthesis temperature and optimal reagent delivery, which may ensure superior quality and minimize batch-to-batch variability. The proposed technology may transform nanoparticle production in laboratories, facilitating nanotechnology-based research and innovation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

The NanoSynth project set out to transform how metallic nanoparticles are produced by developing a fully automated synthesis instrument. Nanoparticles, tiny materials thousands of times smaller than the width of a human hair, hold great promise in fields like medicine, electronics, and environmental science. However, they are often difficult to make with consistent quality and at larger volumes. Through our participation in the NSF I-Corps program, we combined scientific innovation with extensive customer discovery to understand and address these challenges.

Intellectual Merit

Our team investigated a new approach to consistently producing nanoparticles, focusing on precise control over size and shape during synthesis. By speaking directly with more than 100 potential users ranging from academic researchers to industry professionals we identified critical limitations in traditional synthesis methods and vendor-supplied materials. These discussions revealed two major issues: (1) quality inconsistencies that frequently undermined experiments, and (2) limited options for producing nanoparticles of different shapes or at larger volumes. We used this feedback to refine NanoSynth’s technical design, with the goal of creating a more robust and adaptable system.

Broader Impacts

From the start, the NanoSynth project was designed to benefit both research and industry communities. By offering a more reliable way to make nanoparticles in-house, laboratories can reduce costs, save time, and maintain strict oversight of quality control. This is particularly important for researchers conducting sensitive biomedical experiments, where even slight variability in nanoparticle properties can affect results. Equally important, our project served as a real-world training ground for the next generation of engineers and entrepreneurs. Two M.Eng students on our team learned firsthand about customer-focused innovation, market research, and the essential steps in moving technology from the lab to the marketplace. Throughout the course of this project, we discovered that academic and industrial needs overlap: both groups want consistent, high-quality nanoparticles without relying heavily on outside vendors. However, commercial users also require larger batch sizes and a wider variety of particle types. These findings informed our decision to pursue additional R&D, ensuring that future versions of the NanoSynth can handle larger-scale production and more versatile nanoparticle morphologies.

Summary of Outcomes

Over the life of this award, our team accomplished the following:

(1) Developed and tested an automated nanoparticle synthesizer suitable for small-batch production of gold and silver nanoparticles.

(2) Interviewed a wide range of stakeholders including university professors, lab managers, industry engineers, and government researchers to confirm the unmet need for reliable nanoparticle fabrication methods.

(3) Confirmed that while academics value the freedom to customize nanoparticle sizes and shapes, industrial partners require scalable production to meet bigger demands.

(4) Created a clearer roadmap for refining NanoSynth, including improved production capacity, expanded nanoparticle types, and a possible business model that integrates the sale of specialized reagents.

Moving forward, the NanoSynth project will focus on adapting the instrument to fit large-scale and more varied synthesis capabilities. We believe that by continuing to refine both the technology and our understanding of the market, NanoSynth can become a cornerstone in the growing field of nanoparticle research and commercialization. Ultimately, our automated approach promises to help scientists and engineers worldwide achieve more consistent experimental results and unlock new technological applications.

 


Last Modified: 03/07/2025
Modified by: Samuel Bernard Mabbott
